de.awi.floenavigation.initialsetup

Class MMSIFragment

  • java.lang.Object
    • android.support.v4.app.Fragment
      • de.awi.floenavigation.initialsetup.MMSIFragment
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.arch.lifecycle.LifecycleOwner, android.arch.lifecycle.ViewModelStoreOwner, android.content.ComponentCallbacks, android.view.View.OnClickListener, android.view.View.OnCreateContextMenuListener

    public class MMSIFragment
extends android.support.v4.app.Fragment
implements android.view.View.OnClickListener
    This Fragment runs on top of the GridSetupActivity and shows the layout for inserting the first two Fixed/Base Station. This fragment is run twice during the setup process once each for the Origin and x-Axis Marker.
    See Also:
    GridSetupActivity, de.awi.floenavigation.initialsetup

      • onClickConfirm

        public void onClickConfirm()
        Checks the validity of the Station Name and MMSI entered and calls insertStation(String, int) to insert the values in the Database. If the station is inserted successfully it changes the Fragment to CoordinateFragment and passes it the mmsi and aisStationName in the Bundle.

      • validateMMSINumber

        private boolean validateMMSINumber(android.widget.EditText mmsi)
        Parameters:
        mmsi - the EditText for the MMSI field on the Layout
        Returns:
        true if the MMSI field is not empty, contains only digits and has a valid length (specified by VALID_MMSI_LENGTH)

      • insertStation

        private boolean insertStation(java.lang.String AISStationName,
                              int MMSI)
        Inserts a Fixed Station MMSI and other initial values in the Database tables DatabaseHelper.fixedStationTable, DatabaseHelper.stationListTable and DatabaseHelper.baseStationTable. Before inserting in the Database tables it checks if the Station is already installed as a BaseStation and shows a Toast message to that effect. It then inserts the name, MMSI and other parameters in their respective columns in the database tables. The first station being installed is also marked as the Origin in the Database table DatabaseHelper.baseStationTable. Depending on whether it's the first station being installed or second different initialization values of x and y position are inserted in the Database tables. If the MMSI being added is a mobile station it removes from the Database table DatabaseHelper.mobileStationTable and then inserts the name and MMSI of the Fixed Station to the Database tables DatabaseHelper.fixedStationTable, DatabaseHelper.stationListTable and DatabaseHelper.baseStationTable.
        Returns:
        true if the station is inserted successfully.
        See Also:
        DatabaseHelper, ContentValues

      • checkStationInMobileTable

        private boolean checkStationInMobileTable(android.database.sqlite.SQLiteDatabase db,
                                          int MMSI)
        Checks if the given MMSI already exists in DatabaseHelper.mobileStationTable
        Parameters:
        db - An instance SQLiteDatabase
        MMSI - The MMSI number to be checked
        Returns:

      • baseStationRetrievalfromDB

        private int baseStationRetrievalfromDB(android.database.sqlite.SQLiteDatabase db,
                                       int MMSI)
        Checks if the MMSI passed to it already exists in the Database table DatabaseHelper.baseStationTable.
        Parameters:
        db - an instance of SQLiteDatabase
        MMSI - MMSI number of the Station being installed.
        Returns:
        MMSI number of the Base Station if it exists else returns 0.
